In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  approach  paper  for  India’s  Twelfth  Five-Year  Plan  (2012–2017)  indicates  that 
approximately $1 trillion will be required to finance infrastructure investment to maintain the 
targeted gross domestic product growth rate of 9% during the plan period.1  With banks already 
reaching the bank regulatory limits on exposure to infrastructure, the key to reaching this target 
will be to develop a delivery mechanism that can effectively make the economy’s large pool of 
savings available for needed long-term infrastructure investments. 
 
2.  Although  equity  markets  are  well  developed  within  the  Indian  capital  markets,  the 
corporate bond market is quite small, with very limited access for issuers with local credit ratings 
below AA, thereby limiting the financing available to infrastructure developers. The proposed 
approach to expand access of investment grade corporations (i.e., those rated at least BBB-) to 
the corporate bond market, through a credit enhancement mechanism, would be to introduce a 
bond guarantee agency by building on the lessons from the Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations (ASEAN) Bond Markets Initiative (ABMI). 
 
3.  India has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to examine the modalities, 
scope, and potential for the establishment of a bond guarantee fund for India (BGFI) that (i) 
serves India’s unique institutional and regulatory environment; and (ii) supports the development 
of the local currency bond market, to meet India’s infrastructure and non-infrastructure financing 
requirements. The TA is aligned with ADB’s country partnership strategy 2009–2012,2 which 
emphasizes  supporting  infrastructure  investment  in  India  to  meet  the  country’s  large 
infrastructure  deficit  by  catalyzing  investment  and  facilitating  private  sector  participation  in 
infrastructure development. The TA first appeared as a firm 2011 non-lending product in ADB’s 
India country operations business plan 2011–2013.3  
 
4.  The proposed TA is closely linked to the approved guarantee facility for project bonds. 4 
The proposed TA will examine the lessons from credit enhancement of project bonds to study 
the feasibility of providing credit enhancements through guarantees on a standalone basis as a 
separate line of business. Typically guarantee products are offered by specialized entities (such 
as monocline insurers) having specialized features and skills. The TA will thus provide guidance 
on the modalities and operation aspects of such a specialized entity. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.5  
  
II.  ISSUES 
5.  The  TA  supports  a  key  emerging  development  strategy  in  India  for  financing 
infrastructure  and  developing  the  bond  market.  To  make  an  effective  contribution  to  the 
aggregate infrastructure financing in India, the equity for BGFI should be substantial. With a 
leverage  ratio  of  1:4,  for  example,  a  capital  of  $1  billion  (potentially  shared  between  the 
government, ADB, and other donors) would be required to extend bond guarantees of about $4 
billion. This level of guarantee would amount to about 20% of the corporate bonds outstanding 
at  the  end  of  2010. The  participation  of  other  parties  and/or  a  higher  contribution  by  the 
government  could  augment  the  capital  and  the  guarantee  capacity  of  BGFI.  To  meet  the

incremental capital–output ratio of approximately 4 over the plan period.

2   
objective of financing $1 trillion of infrastructure investments in the next five-year plan, the 
capacity of BGFI would need to be further extended.  
 
6.  While there may  be  limited  instances  initially  in  which  BGFI  would  want  to  extend 
guarantees above the AAA domestic rating, there may be an opportunity cost in not aspiring to 
the  AAA  international  rating,  which  would  allow  BGFI  to  assist  domestic  issuers  to  enter 
international markets. To achieve the desired rating upgrade for its infrastructure corporate 
clients, BGFI could employ partial or full guarantees. 
 
7.  With its guarantees, BGFI would have a significant impact on the development of the 
corporate  bond  market  by  increasing  the  supply  of  AA  and  above-rated  bonds  from  the 
infrastructure and non-infrastructure corporate sector, thereby promoting the expansion of the 
corporate bond market. With credit protection, BGFI would help broaden investor base for local 
rupee-denominated bonds by making it possible for domestic institutional investors, especially 
insurance and pension funds, to invest in credit-enhanced corporate bonds. Moreover, based on 
the  experience  of  other  markets  (e.g.,  in  Singapore)  this  would  gradually  increase  the 
acceptance and demand for investment-rated corporate issues which could even be rated below 
AA, and provide firms with the option of future direct access to the corporate bond market. 
 
8.  Capacity development. Bond guarantees are new in India with the first infrastructure 
bond  issuances  being  supported  under  the  Guarantee  Facility  for  Credit  Enhancement  of 
Project Bonds (footnote 4). While there is a felt need in the market for the credit enhancement 
product and a pipeline is under discussion with respect to the above facility, several capacity 
constraints exist in the market to mainstream the guarantee product. Specifically, these relate to 
(i) due diligence for undertaking longer tenor fixed rate risk as required for bond exposures; (ii) 
structuring of security packages and indemnities for secured parties under a bond guarantee; (iii) 
guarantee structuring based on the stand-alone rating; (iv) pricing of first loss guarantee (which 
is new in India), compared with pari passu guarantee; and (v) need to evolve the guarantee 
product to include pricing and structuring of greenfield risk.6 Thus, a key objective of the BGFI 
would be to disseminate best practices with respect to the above issues to all stakeholders 
which is critical if complex guarantee structures are to evolve and gain wider acceptance in the 
Indian market.        
 
9.  Fees. The guarantee fees would be charged on the basis of the market spread and the 
reduced interest cost accorded through the guarantee upgrade. The benefit that BGFI accords 
the issuer through lower interest rates would be shared in part with the issuer, although the 
majority of the gains would go to BGFI to cover its risks. If the spreads available in the market 
were not adequate to cover the cost of capital, the guarantee would need to be declined.7 
 
10.  Governance. The governance of BGFI is a crucial factor that must be resolved in 
consultation  with  the  government  to  ensure  that  a  credit  culture  permeates  BGFI  on  a 
sustainable basis. While guarantees are easy to give, it is difficult to sustain the dedication to 
financial due diligence required for profitable and sustainable operation of BGFI, without an 
enabling  internal  governance  structure.  Diversified  ownership  could  be  considered  to  help 
                                                
6  Credit rating agencies typically require a first loss guarantee structure to recognize any credible level of rating 
upgrade. A first loss guarantee covers the entire bond service obligation on interest payment dates, covering 
interest and principal payments up to a maximum cap amount, rather than partially covering a portion of debt 
service to bond holders. However, this modality which is particularly suited for the infrastructure sector, requires 
further dissemination in the Indian market.  
7  A key capacity building aspect would be to structure the guarantee and evaluate projects and security structures to 
reduce the extent of guarantee cover required in order to reduce guarantee fees.

3 
promote governance within the board of directors, as could governance approaches such as 
making the chief credit officer report directly to the risk management committee of the board, 
while having a say in reporting guarantees to the board for their approval. 
 
11.  International experience and learning. While BGFI focuses on India, the experiences 
and lessons of ASEAN+3 with respect to the findings of the TA will be shared with other 
countries in the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) region through 
convening of dedicated seminars under this TA. The first seminar could be (i) an ASEAN+3 
seminar comprising participants at the working group level including selective representatives 
from India and one or two of SAARC countries with most developed bond markets; and (ii) a 
seminar inviting relevant officers from SAARC member countries, in particular, representatives 
from the Ministry of Finance, Securities and Exchange Commission, and bond dealers and 
traders, focusing on how these other countries may wish to develop plans for bond market 
development and harmonize their activities with India’s BGFI initiative.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
12.  The impact of this TA is greater access by corporations to the local currency bond 
markets to meet their long-term infrastructure financing needs. A functional BGFI will help to roll 
out and mainstream the credit enhancement product in the Indian financial sector and channel 
India’s large savings pool to the infrastructure and non-infrastructure corporates. Through its 
activities, the BGFI would (i) support a new asset class for institutional investors and investment 
assets,  (ii)  mobilize  additional  long-term  financing  for  infrastructure  development,  and  (iii) 
diversify  infrastructure  funding  sources  to  complement  bank  financing  and  thereby  reduce 
systemic risk to the financial system. The outcome of this TA is to inform the government on the 
benefits and mechanics on the establishment of a successful BGFI. The key TA outputs include 
(i) a detailed framework and institutional arrangements for BGFI, (ii) a blueprint to operationalize 
the BGFI, and (iii) enhanced knowledge on BGFI.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.   The TA would finance the preparation of the studies across the different components 
(see below) to enable the government to decide on the creation the BGFI. The TA will build on 
international best practices including the work that led to the creation of the Credit Guarantee 
and Investment Facility (CGIF) as well as the background studies that have constituted the 
technical due diligence leading to Guarantee Facility for Credit Enhancement of Project Bonds 
(footnote 4). The TA will further develop the ongoing engagement with participating financial 
institutions, in this case, to study best case options for establishing the BGFI given the lessons 
learned from the credit enhancement experience. The activities under the TA will be coordinated 
in  consultation  with  ADB’s  Office  of  Regional  Economic  Integration  (OREI)  to  support  the 
transfer of knowledge from their development of CGIF.  
 
14.  The following key components and  activities will be undertaken.  
 
(i)  Demand Analysis. Comprehensive analysis of the demand for bond issuance by 
investment-rated  infrastructure  and  non-infrastructure  corporations  in  India, 
focusing on the potential volume of such issuance and the needed maturity and 
terms,  and  classifying  potential  issuers  by  (a)  type  of  institutions  (e.g.,  by 
industry); and (b) by size and by rationale of their investment programs in local

4   
currency.  The  analysis  will  also  assess  the  factors  that  favor  and  impede 
investment by these investors and the likely levels of assistance that will be 
afforded through the guarantee operations of BGFI.   
 
(ii)  Structure of BGFI. Based on the recommendations of the demand analysis, a 
key  activity  to  be  undertaken  is  the  determination,  in  conjunction  with  the 
government, of (a) the required and desirable size of BGFI capitalization and 
prudent leverage ratio to meet the demand for local currency bond guarantees 
required  under  the  Twelfth  Five-Year  Plan  (2012–2017);  (b)  comprehensive 
cost–benefit analyses of options to establish BGFI as a trust or as a company, 
including legal requirements, taxes, and prudential regulations that BGFI will 
have to comply with; and (c) a business model for BGFI based on the outcomes 
of the findings above.  
 
(iii)  Knowledge  dissemination.  As  indicated  above  (para.  8),  a  key  capacity 
development aspect is to generate awareness among all stakeholders on key 
aspects of guarantee structuring and pricing. This is all the more important given 
the regional dimension with respect to SAARC to enable member countries to 
benefit from the Indian experience. The planned consultation seminars are key to 
developing this aspect.    
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $960,000, of which $800,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and administered by ADB. The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart remuneration, office accommodation and 
supplies, transport, and other logistical support. The cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The TA will be administered by ADB’s South Asia Department in coordination with OREI, 
which is working with ASEAN+3 as the Secretariat for ABMI. The Department of Financial 
Services of the Ministry of Finance will be the implementing agency. In addition, a steering 
committee chaired by the joint secretary concerned and comprising the Reserve Bank of India, 
the Securities and Exchange Board of India, and the pension and insurance fund regulators will 
be established to coordinate implementation of the TA. A project focal point will be identified to 
coordinate activities across government agencies. The TA will be disbursed in accordance with 
ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
The design and monitoring framework in Appendix 1 will be used to track and evaluate progress 
in implementation. The TA will be implemented in approximately 12 months and is expected to 
begin in February 2013 and be completed by February 2014. 
 
17.   The TA will require 18 person-months of international consulting services and 7 person-
months of national consulting services. The consultants will be engaged by ADB under a 
combination of a firm and as individual consultants in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). An international consulting firm in 
association with national consultants will be selected and engaged by ADB, using the quality- 
and cost-based selection method with a quality–cost weighting of 90:10. The simplified technical 
proposal procedure will be used to select the consultants. The international consultants will 
include financial sector specialists, who will also be the team leader, as well as corporate

5 
governance specialist, accountant, and legal expert. National consultants with expertise in most 
of these areas will be engaged for the same length of time under a firm to provide support to the 
international consultants. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
18.  The team leader will coordinate all consultant inputs. The consultants will submit (i) an 
inception report within 1 month of TA commencement; (ii) an interim progress report, including 
analysis of the demand for bond guarantees by investment-rated corporations and the targeted 
capitalization and governance approaches for BGFI 6 months after TA commencement; (iii) a 
draft final report 7 months after TA commencement; and (iv) a final report after receiving and 
incorporating comments by ADB. The progress of the TA project will be discussed with the 
government on a regular basis with regular reports to the implementing agency. These reports 
are  to  be  shared  with  government  officials  and  market  participants  through  dissemination 
seminars and workshops, as well as with ABMI members in coordination with OREI. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 to the Government 
of India to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for Preparing 
the Bond Guarantee Fund for India, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

B.  National Consultants 
 
5.  The two specialists, legal consultant (4 person-months) and safeguard specialists (3 
person months), will support the international consultants as they undertake their respective 
tasks including determination of legal requirements for the articles of association under Indian 
law, capacity development, project administration, and report preparation, as required. 
 
6.  Legal specialist (4 person-months). Under the guidance of the international legal expert, 
and as required under the first phase recommendations, the legal specialist will

(ii)  facilitate preliminary discussions to enable all stakeholders to appreciate steps 
required to develop incorporation articles of agreement; and 
(iii)  provide  an  overview  of  tasks  required  to  meet  actual  incorporation  and/or 
registration and filing requirements. 
 
7.  Safeguard specialists (3 person-months: 1 social and 1 environmental). The safeguard 
specialists will support the international consultant in undertaking the following tasks: 
  
(i)  review  IIFCL's  ESMS,  incorporate  the  lessons  learned  by  IIFCL  and  Credit 
Guarantee and Investment Facility in implementing their respective ESMS, and 
revise or enhance the ESMS to fit BGFI's operations; 
(ii)   discuss with the implementing agency staff, and suggest how the ESMS could be 
mainstreamed into BGFI's due diligence and credit and risk management and 
monitoring procedure; and 
(iii)   assess the capacity needs of BGFI in implementing the ESMS; based on this, 
design  and/or  conduct  a  training  program  in  implementing  the  ESMS  for 
prospective BGFI staff.
